input.plot: Red and Elias arrive at the cottage, tension running high as Red hesitates at the threshold. Elias stands protectively behind her, his ax ready. When Red knocks, Lucien—posing as Grandmother—welcomes them in, his performance convincing at first. The air is thick with suspicion as Lucien pours tea and offers it to Red, but she challenges him, refusing to drink until he does. Lucien complies to ease her doubts, but the underlying distrust remains. Elias, unsettled by signs of intrusion (muddy boots by the hearth), interrogates Lucien about them, suggesting that danger may already be inside. The conversation turns tense and personal as Lucien abandons his disguise, confessing his deep feelings for Red in a passionate outpouring. Red is shocked by this revelation, torn between the two men and the secrets swirling around her. Lucien then reveals that he was never at the cottage by accident: he was sent by a mysterious Council to protect Red from a greater threat—the Wolf—and that Lucien himself is the Wolf's son. He declares Red is the last heir to a bloodline capable of ending the Wolf, and that Grandmother orchestrated the entire situation, manipulating every choice and danger they've faced. Red reels from these revelations, feeling betrayed by Lucien's secrecy and Grandmother's machinations. Elias supports Red, vowing to help her face the truth together. The chapter ends with Red and Elias confronting the enormity of the secrets revealed, questioning their roles as pawns or family, as the crackle of the hearth and distant caws of crows echo the uncertainty ahead.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: It doesn’t smell like Grandmother’s soup in here. Why is it so dark?

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: Stay close, Red. Something’s off—mind if I set my ax by the door, Grandmother?

dialogue.speaker: Lucien
dialogue.line: Oh, my dear children, come in, come in! No need for weapons here… let’s warm ourselves with some tea.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: You first, Grandmother. Drink with me.

dialogue.speaker: Lucien
dialogue.line: Of course, anything to put your mind at ease.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: Funny, those boots by the hearth are caked with mud—did you go out walking, ma’am?

dialogue.speaker: Lucien
dialogue.line: The woods are restless these days, Elias. I had to check the traps before you arrived.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: You never set traps, Grandmother. You said kindness keeps away the wolves.

dialogue.speaker: Lucien
dialogue.line: Enough! I tire of this charade. Red, it’s me—Lucien. I never wanted to deceive you, but you must hear the truth.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: Lucien? What have you done with her?

dialogue.speaker: Lucien
dialogue.line: She’s safe. I only wanted to protect you, Red. I—I care for you, more than words can say. I’d do anything to keep you from harm… even if it means lying.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: You lied to me. How can I trust anything you say now?

dialogue.speaker: Lucien
dialogue.line: Because I am no ordinary visitor. The Council sent me to guard you. I am the Wolf’s son—and you, Red, are the last of the line that can put an end to him.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: That’s impossible. Why would Grandmother allow any of this?

dialogue.speaker: Lucien
dialogue.line: Because she’s orchestrated everything. Every danger, every turn—she wanted you to choose, Red, not just play along.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: All this time, I was just a piece in her game… My whole life, shaped by secrets.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: You’re not alone, Red. Whatever’s ahead, we face it together. I won’t let anyone else decide your fate.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Are we family, or are we pawns? I need to know who I am—on my own terms.

input.plot: Red slices rye bread as her mother discovers a wax-sealed letter on the doorstep, its pine-resin scent raising suspicion. Her mother, anxious, asks Red to fetch the lamp so they can examine the letter together. Red, however, asserts her determination to read the letter herself, emphasizing her need to face whatever truths or warnings it contains. Despite her mother’s pleas to be cautious and reminders of past troubles, Red insists on uncovering the truth, expressing compassion for her mother’s fears but refusing to let them hold her back. Red’s mother warns of the dangers of family secrets, but Red, resolute, states that hiding from them would only make things worse. With trembling hands but a steady heart, Red opens the letter, determined to discover Grandmother’s cryptic message, while her mother remains anxious but unable to dissuade her.

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.line: Red, come quickly—there’s something odd at the door. Smells of pine and secrets.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Let me see it, Mother. I need to know what Grandmother wants to tell us, no matter what it is.

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.line: Please, darling, be careful. Letters sealed in wax rarely bring good news for our family.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: I won't let fear dictate my choices. It's time I faced these shadows myself.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: Red, if you need me, I’m right outside. You don’t have to do this alone.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Thank you, Elias. But I must read it first.

dialogue.speaker: Lucien Wolf
dialogue.line: Curiosity is a dangerous fire, Red. Some truths bite back.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Perhaps, Lucien. But ignoring them only gives them sharper teeth.

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.line: Family secrets can ruin lives, Red. Please, think before you open that letter.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: It’s because I care for you, Mother, that I need to know. We can’t keep living in fear.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.line: You always were braver than you knew, my Red. The answers are yours to claim.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Then I claim them now, whatever they may be.

input.plot: Red and Elias move carefully along the forest path toward Grandmother’s cottage, with Red alert for any sign of danger. As they cross the mossy bridge, Lucien Wolf appears, emerging from the shadows in a mud-spattered cloak. He introduces himself as a lost traveler, but Red immediately challenges his intentions, pressing him to reveal his true purpose in the woods. Lucien admits he seeks something that was taken from him and hints at the woods’ hidden secrets, suggesting his motives are more personal and urgent than he first claimed. Tension escalates as Elias steps protectively between Red and Lucien, warning him to stay back. Lucien, unfazed, shares a story of once being lost in the woods and proposes a shortcut through the undergrowth, claiming it might reveal important truths. Red and Elias refuse the offer, debating the risks of venturing off the safe path. Red firmly chooses the marked trail, asserting her agency and asking Elias to trust her judgment. Lucien, denied, watches them with narrowed eyes, his motives and past with the woods left ambiguous as he disappears into the shadows, the air thick with secrets and unspoken threats.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Hold up, Elias. Did you hear that rustling behind the oaks? Someone’s there.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: Stay close, Red. I’ll go first—no one’s slipping past me.

dialogue.speaker: Lucien Wolf
dialogue.line: My apologies for startling you. I’m merely a traveler—lost, it seems, in your woods.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Lost? Or searching for something you shouldn’t have touched? These woods remember strangers.

dialogue.speaker: Lucien Wolf
dialogue.line: Sharp eyes, little Red. I’ll admit, I’m after something precious, stolen from me under this very canopy.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: Step back, Lucien. If you’ve got business, it’s not with her.

dialogue.speaker: Lucien Wolf
dialogue.line: Relax, friend. I’ve wandered lost here before—sometimes the forest itself hides the answers you seek.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: If you know so much, why not walk the marked trail? I trust my own path more than shortcuts through thorns.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: I agree with Red. We’ll stick to the safe way, thanks.

dialogue.speaker: Lucien Wolf
dialogue.line: Suit yourselves. The straight road rarely leads to the truth, but perhaps you’ll learn that yet.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Come on, Elias. Let’s keep moving—and next time, let me handle the wolves.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: As you wish, Red. I trust your instincts.

dialogue.speaker: Lucien Wolf
dialogue.line: I’ll be seeing you again, I’m sure. The woods always bring secrets to light.

input.plot: Red approaches the cottage door, gripping her basket tightly. She brushes aside a hanging sprig of rosemary as she knocks twice, the hollow sound echoing inside. Elias paces a short distance behind her, scanning the shadowed tree line, his axe resting on his shoulder. When no answer comes, Red pushes the door open; it creaks, revealing an unlit interior. She steps inside, running her fingers over the cold hearthstones, noting the untouched teacup and the absence of Grandmother's shawl. Elias follows, sniffing the air for unfamiliar scents, then inspects muddy footprints near the back window. Red quietly calls for her grandmother, her voice low and deliberate, while Elias checks the pantry for signs of recent use. Their coordinated search reveals no sign of Grandmother, only a faint musky odor lingering near her bed. Red exchanges a wary glance with Elias, both now alert to the peculiar silence and the sense of intrusion.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: Grandmother? It's me, Red... Are you here?
dialogue.action: Red stands just inside the doorway, her hand resting on the frame as she peers into the dimly lit room. Her voice trembles slightly, betraying her unease, as she scans the shadows for any sign of her grandmother.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: No fresh crumbs, and the flour tin's barely touched—it's like nobody's baked here in days.
dialogue.action: Elias runs his finger along the dusty shelf, frowning as he glances back toward Red.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: Grandmother, can you hear me? Please answer, it's so quiet in here...
dialogue.action: Red edges closer to the bedroom door, her hand trembling as she rests it on the old brass knob, her eyes darting to Elias for reassurance.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: Red, the bread’s stale and there’s dust on the shelves—if your grandmother’s been here, she hasn’t eaten in a while.
dialogue.action: Elias kneels to inspect a set of faint footprints in the flour on the floor, his brow furrowed with worry.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: It's not like her to stay so silent—she always greets me before I even reach the door.
dialogue.action: Red clutches her basket tighter, glancing nervously at the shadowy hallway beyond the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: Maybe she's resting, but something feels wrong—the air's heavy, like someone's been hiding here.
dialogue.action: Elias runs his fingers along the pantry doorframe, frowning as he studies a faint, unfamiliar footprint in the dust.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: Grandmother, if you're here, please say something—I'm starting to get scared.
dialogue.action: Red steps forward, her hand trembling as she clutches her basket, eyes scanning the dim corners of the room.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: Red, look—there’s a muddy footprint by the back door, too large to be hers.
dialogue.action: Elias crouches beside the print, tracing its outline with a tense finger as he glances back at Red.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: Then who could it belong to, Elias?
dialogue.action: Red edges closer to Elias, her voice trembling, as she glances anxiously toward the shadowy corners of the room.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: I don't know, but we need to be careful—someone else might be inside.
dialogue.action: Elias lowers his voice, motioning for Red to stay behind him as he steps cautiously toward the hallway.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: Grandmother, if you're in trouble, make a sound—anything—so we know you're safe.
dialogue.action: Red edges closer to the bedroom door, her hand trembling as she reaches for the handle, while Elias scans the shadows behind her, tense and alert.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: Red, stay close—I’ll check the bedroom, but keep your eyes open for anything out of place.
dialogue.action: Elias quietly steps toward the dim hallway, his hand hovering near the old lantern as he listens for any movement.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: Elias, the sheets are rumpled, but there's no sign of her—it's like she vanished.
dialogue.action: Red clutches her basket tighter, her gaze darting anxiously around the dimly lit room.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: Elias, the window's open just a crack—and I think I see a scrap of her shawl caught on the latch.
dialogue.action: Red edges toward the window, her hand trembling as she reaches for the piece of fabric.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: Her shawl—she wouldn't leave it behind unless she left in a hurry; Elias, what if she's trying to signal us?
dialogue.action: Red clutches the scrap of shawl, her hands trembling, and peers anxiously out the window into the shadowy yard.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: Elias, what if she’s hiding somewhere close, waiting for us to find her?
dialogue.action: Red clutches the edge of the shawl, her voice trembling as she scans the shadows of the room.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: I'll check under the bed—maybe she dropped something else, something to help us find her.
dialogue.action: Red kneels beside the bed, her hands trembling as she lifts the quilt, searching for another sign of her grandmother.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: Elias, there's a button here on the floor—it's from her cardigan, I'm sure of it.
dialogue.action: Red kneels beside the bed, holding up the button with trembling fingers, her eyes searching Elias's face for reassurance.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: Elias, the room feels colder all of a sudden—do you think someone else is still here, watching us?
dialogue.action: Red clutches the button tightly in her fist, her eyes darting nervously around the shadowy corners of the room.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.dialogue: Elias: Stay behind me, Red—I hear a floorboard creaking in the hallway, and we're not alone.
dialogue.action: Elias steps protectively in front of Red, his hand tightening around the handle of a nearby fire iron as he listens intently toward the hallway.

dialogue.speaker: Red (Red Riding Hood)
dialogue.dialogue: Elias, my heart's pounding—should we call out again, or stay quiet and listen?
dialogue.action: Red clutches her basket closer, her eyes wide as she strains to hear any movement beyond the door.

input.plot: Red steps carefully along the muddy path, her basket swinging from one arm as she scans the undergrowth for movement. She pauses at the sound of chopping wood and sees Elias, the woodsman, splitting logs with steady precision, his boots sunk into the soft earth. Intent on reaching her grandmother’s cottage, Red approaches and greets him with cautious politeness. Elias straightens, wipes the sweat from his brow, and expresses concern for Red’s safety, mentioning rumors of wolves nearby. Red initially hesitates, not wanting to trouble him or delay his work, but admits to hearing something strange in the trees. Elias insists on accompanying her, reassuring Red with his practical advice and protective presence. As they set off together, Elias points out safe trails and warns her of hidden roots, his voice low and practical. The mist thickens as they walk, the forest closing in, and Red remains alert, her wariness gradually softening as Elias gently steadies her when she stumbles on a mossy stone. Their footsteps blend with the rhythm of the woods, the path ahead opening just enough to promise safety if they move together.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Good morning, Elias. The woods seem restless today, don’t they?

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: Morning, Red. You’re out early—and alone. Heard talk of wolves prowling these parts; it’s not safe.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: I wouldn’t want to keep you from your work. But something’s been following me, I think. The trees feel... different.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: That settles it. I’ll walk with you—wood can wait. Stay close, and watch your step; these roots like to trip the unwary.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Thank you, Elias. I know the path well, but it changes when the mist comes.

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: Mist hides more than stones, Red. If you lose your footing, let me steady you.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: I heard a howl last night, too close for comfort. Do you really think wolves are near?

dialogue.speaker: Elias
dialogue.line: Wouldn’t risk it if I didn’t. Promise me you’ll call out if you sense anything strange.

input.plot: Red enters the cottage, her boots damp with forest dew, carrying a basket of wildflowers. She finds Grandmother mending a crimson cloak by the hearth. Grandmother presents her with two sealed letters—one from Elias, one from Lucien Wolf—and tells Red she may open only one, warning her that the unopened letter will remain a silence she must carry. Red hesitates, torn by the gravity of the choice. She asks if choosing one means forsaking the other forever, and Grandmother confirms that the path she chooses is final. After a moment of internal struggle, Red chooses Elias’s letter, accepting the consequences, but then asserts her independence: she declares she will not let letters or matchmaking schemes define her fate, and vows to forge her own path, regardless of the world’s expectations. Grandmother acknowledges Red’s resolve with a mixture of concern and respect, marking a shift in their relationship toward mutual understanding.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Grandmother, why must I choose? If I open one, is the other lost to me forever?

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.line: Some doors close as others open, my dear. The silence of an unopened letter shapes its own shadow in your life.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: It feels cruel to decide when I barely know what each holds. What if I regret it?

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.line: Regret is the price of every true choice. But indecision is its own prison.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Then I choose Elias’s letter. I won’t let uncertainty tether me.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.line: You carry courage, child. Yet remember, every chosen path leaves a story untold.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: Stories may try to bind me, but I refuse to be written by anyone else. My fate is my own, letters or no letters.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.line: Wise words for one so young. Still, independence can be a lonely companion.

dialogue.speaker: Red's Mother
dialogue.line: Red, promise me you’ll be careful. The world is full of secrets—some best left unread.

dialogue.speaker: Red
dialogue.line: I promise, Mother. But I won’t run from truth, or from myself.
